text.p: The following are the main stories from Tuesday's Albanian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Newspaper editorial says pyramid schemes, Kosovo issue and presidential elections will be the main features of 1997.
- The year 1997 will be more expensive than 1996 for Albanians following an approximate price rise of 20 percent over the past year.
- Ibrahim Rugova, self-declared president of the ethnic Albanians of the Serbian province of Kosovo, is in conflict with Albanian authorities over many issues relating to the Kosovo question.
- Right-wing National Front party and the monarchic Legality Movement have formed an alliance.
- Albania's opposition Socialist Party rejected a pardon by conservative President Sali Berisha which reduced the jail term of their leader Fatos Nano by six months.
- Berisha issued a decree on Sunday pardoning or reducing the jail sentences of 102 prisoners.

- The appeals court turned down a request to change the detention conditions of Klement Kolaneci, son-in-law of the late communist leader Enver Hoxha, who was arrested last October in connection with a guerrilla group.
- Halit Shamata, interior minister, said on Sunday state- organised structures must fight organised crime, guerrilla activities, drug trafficking, illegal immigration, fraud, and smuggling.
- Gjallica, a pyramid scheme company, temporarily stopped giving returns and started investigating two of its staff for suspected embezzlement.
- Bledar Xhuli, an Albanian immigrant in Italy, was declared the man of the year in Milan by the Vatican newspaper Avvenire.
